jorisvandenbossche commented on issue #4244:  ARROW-3650: [Python] warn on converting DataFrame with mixed type column names
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4244#issuecomment-489115785
 
 
   There is one problem with this PR: it also generates a warning if you have a `None` as column name (so mix of int or string with None in an object dtype Index object), while for this case we actually roundtrip correctly:
   
   ```
   In [62]: df = pd.DataFrame(np.random.randn(2, 2), columns=['a', None])                                                                                                          
   
   In [63]: pa.Table.from_pandas(df).to_pandas().columns                                                                                                                           
   Out[63]: Index(['a', None], dtype='object')
   ```
   
   But I don't think it is that easy to detect this case, to not warn in that case (I certainly could do it, but IMO would lead to unnecessary code complexity). So it seems it is a choice between no warning at all (as it is currently), or warning in the mixed case including for this specific case where the warning is incorrect. 
   I don't feel strongly about either of them (it are corner cases anyway).
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on to GitHub and use the
URL above to go to the specific comment.
 
For queries about this service, please contact Infrastructure at:
users@infra.apache.org

jorisvandenbossche commented on issue #4244:  ARROW-3650: [Python] warn on converting DataFrame with mixed type column names
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4244#issuecomment-489115785
 
 
   There is one problem with this PR: it also generates a warning if you have a `None` as column name (so mix of int or string with None in an object dtype Index object), while for this case we actually roundtrip correctly:
   
   ```
   In [62]: df = pd.DataFrame(np.random.randn(2, 2), columns=['a', None])
   
   In [63]: pa.Table.from_pandas(df).to_pandas().columns
   /home/joris/miniconda3/envs/arrow-dev/bin/ipython:1: UserWarning: The DataFrame has column
   names of mixed type. They will be converted to strings and not roundtrip correctly.
   Out[63]: Index(['a', None], dtype='object')
   ```
   
   But I don't think it is that easy to detect this case, to not warn in that case (I certainly could do it, but IMO would lead to unnecessary code complexity). So it seems it is a choice between no warning at all (as it is currently), or warning in the mixed case including for this specific case where the warning is incorrect. 
   I don't feel strongly about either of them (it are corner cases anyway).
 
----------------------------------------------------------------

jorisvandenbossche commented on issue #4244:  ARROW-3650: [Python] warn on converting DataFrame with mixed type column names
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4244#issuecomment-489662715
 
 
   Not sure why someone would ever do that on purpose (also when you have no index name (meaning it is `None`), and you reset the index (meaning: converting it to a column), pandas creates a default index name like 'index' or 'level_0', so you don't end up with a column name `None` in that common case). 
   
   There is a case where you can end up with NaNs in your index or column names (that is not too far stretched), eg when pivoting / unstacking data and your data contains NaNs:
   
   ```
   In [4]: df = pd.DataFrame({'A' : [0, 0, 1, 1], 'B': ['a', 'b', 'a', np.nan], 'C':[1, 2, 3, 4]})
   
   In [5]: df
   Out[5]: 
      A    B  C
   0  0    a  1
   1  0    b  2
   2  1    a  3
   3  1  NaN  4
   
   In [6]: df2 = df.pivot(index='A', columns='B', values='C')
   
   In [7]: df2
   Out[7]: 
   B  NaN    a    b
   A               
   0  NaN  1.0  2.0
   1  4.0  3.0  NaN
   
   In [8]: df2.columns
   Out[8]: Index([nan, 'a', 'b'], dtype='object', name='B')
   
   In [9]: table = pa.Table.from_pandas(df2)
   /home/joris/miniconda3/envs/arrow-dev/bin/ipython:1: UserWarning: The DataFrame has column
   names of mixed type. They will be converted to strings and not roundtrip correctly.
   
   
   In [10]: table
   Out[10]: 
   pyarrow.Table
   nan: double
   a: double
   b: double
   A: int64
   metadata
   --------
   {b'pandas': b'{"index_columns": ["A"], "column_indexes": [{"name": "B", "field'
               b'_name": "B", "pandas_type": "mixed", "numpy_type": "object", "me'
               b'tadata": null}], "columns": [{"name": "nan", "field_name": "nan"'
               b', "pandas_type": "float64", "numpy_type": "float64", "metadata":'
               b' null}, {"name": "a", "field_name": "a", "pandas_type": "float64'
               b'", "numpy_type": "float64", "metadata": null}, {"name": "b", "fi'
               b'eld_name": "b", "pandas_type": "float64", "numpy_type": "float64'
               b'", "metadata": null}, {"name": "A", "field_name": "A", "pandas_t'
               b'ype": "int64", "numpy_type": "int64", "metadata": null}], "creat'
               b'or": {"library": "pyarrow", "version": "0.13.1.dev130+gdd335952"'
               b'}, "pandas_version": "0.24.2"}'}
   
   In [11]: table.to_pandas()
   Out[11]: 
   B  nan    a    b
   A               
   0  NaN  1.0  2.0
   1  4.0  3.0  NaN
   
   In [12]: table.to_pandas().columns
   Out[12]: Index(['nan', 'a', 'b'], dtype='object', name='B')
   ```
   
   But apparently (seeing this now as I was trying the above), NaNs indeed don't roundtrip correctly (so in that case the warning is appropriate), and it is only `None` that we reconstruct faithfully:
   
   ```
   In [17]: df3 = pd.DataFrame([[1, 2], [3, 4]], columns=['a', None])
   
   In [18]: df3.columns
   Out[18]: Index(['a', None], dtype='object')
   
   In [19]: table = pa.Table.from_pandas(df3)
   /home/joris/miniconda3/envs/arrow-dev/bin/ipython:1: UserWarning: The DataFrame has column
   names of mixed type. They will be converted to strings and not roundtrip correctly.
   
   In [20]: table
   Out[20]: 
   pyarrow.Table
   a: int64
   None: int64
   metadata
   --------
   {b'pandas': b'{"index_columns": [{"kind": "range", "name": null, "start": 0, "'
               b'stop": 2, "step": 1}], "column_indexes": [{"name": null, "field_'
               b'name": null, "pandas_type": "mixed", "numpy_type": "object", "me'
               b'tadata": null}], "columns": [{"name": "a", "field_name": "a", "p'
               b'andas_type": "int64", "numpy_type": "int64", "metadata": null}, '
               b'{"name": null, "field_name": "None", "pandas_type": "int64", "nu'
               b'mpy_type": "int64", "metadata": null}], "creator": {"library": "'
               b'pyarrow", "version": "0.13.1.dev130+gdd335952"}, "pandas_version'
               b'": "0.24.2"}'}
   
   In [22]: table.to_pandas().columns
   Out[22]: Index(['a', None], dtype='object')
   ```
   
   So here the actual `None` is preserved when converting back to pandas (since we have `"name": null, "field_name": "None"` in the metadata), and the warning is not correct. 
   But I *think* having None like that in your column names is less likely than having NaN in your column names.
   
   
 
----------------------------------------------------------------

issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

fields.description:
Consider the following example: 

{code:java}
df = pd.DataFrame(1, index=[pd.to_datetime('2018/01/01')], columns=['a string', pd.to_datetime('2018/01/02')])

table = pa.Table.from_pandas(df)
pq.write_table(table, 'test.parquet')

ref_df = pq.read_pandas('test.parquet').to_pandas()

print(df.columns)
# Index(['a string', 2018-01-02 00:00:00], dtype='object')
print(ref_df.columns)
# Index(['a string', '2018-01-02 00:00:00'], dtype='object')
{code}

The serialized data frame has an index with a string and a datetime field (happened when resetting the index of a formerly datetime only column).
When reading the string back the datetime is converted into a string.

When looking at the schema I find {{"pandas_type": "mixed", "numpy_ty'
            b'pe": "object"}} before serializing and {{"pandas_type": "unicode", "numpy_'
            b'type": "object"}} after reading back. So the schema was aware of the mixed type but did not store the actual types.

The same happens with other types like numbers as well. One can produce interesting situations:

{{pd.DataFrame(1, index=[pd.to_datetime('2018/01/01')], columns=['1', 1])}} can be written but fails to be read back as the index is no more unique with '1' showing up two times.

IIf this is not a bug but expected maybe the user should be somehow warned that information is lost? Like a {{NotImplemented}} exception.
fields.summary: [Python] Mixed column indexes are read back as strings

comments.body: Seems the coercion is happening in {{table = pa.Table.from_pandas(df)}}. Would you like to submit a PR to add a warning?
